awd_titl_txt: MRI Consortium:  Development of a Forward Calorimetry Upgrade  for the STAR Detector
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics, or QCD, is considered a cornerstone of modern physics. As the fundamental theory of the nuclear force, it describes strongly interacting matter in terms of point-like quarks bound together via exchange of massless particles called gluons. Yet despite its remarkable success in explaining measurements carried out at the highest energies, a detailed understanding of low-energy phenomena, such as the internal structure of the protons and neutrons that make up 99% of the visible mass of the universes, remains elusive theoretically and must be gained through experiment. Over the last few decades, much progress has been made in this area, but not for the very low or very high energy constituents within the proton. This project will upgrade the STAR detector in order to make possible the study of proton-proton collision products at far-forward angles, a kinematic regime dominated by the scattering of high-momentum quarks on low-momentum gluons. This study will provide a unique opportunity to explore how the quarks, gluons, and their spins are distributed in space and momentum. Using the same techniques in proton-nucleus collisions will allow for a better understanding of how properties of protons and neutrons are modified in the nuclear environment. That in turn will improve the understanding of nucleus-nucleus collisions.

The STAR forward upgrade is designed to explore QCD physics in the very high and low regions of partonic momentum fraction, a kinematic regime that has thus far remained inaccessible at RHIC. It will provide superior detection and reconstruction capabilities for neutral pions, photons, electrons, jets, and leading hadrons over the pseudo-rapidity range 2.5-4. To reduce costs and risk, much of the detector package will consist of previously used components. The electromagnetic calorimeter will use refurbished sampling Pb-scintillator blocks from PHENIX. The hadronic calorimeter will be a sandwich iron-scintillator plate sampling type, designed and prototyped with separate R&D funds. Both calorimeters will share the same cost-effective readout electronics, and will use SiPMs as photo-sensors, thereby allowing them to operate without shielding in high magnetic fields and high radiation environments, as will be encountered in this location. By design, the system is scalable and reconfigurable: the EMCal blocks are simply stacked vertically, while HCal "slabs" will be assembled in place. Integration into STAR will require only minimal modification of existing infrastructure. Based on detailed GEANT simulations, the Forward Calorimetry System (FCS) will have very good electromagnetic (10% / sqrt(E) + 3%) and hadronic (~50% / sqrt(E) + 10%) energy resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This MRI award enabled members of the Solenoidal Tracker at RHIC (“STAR”) Collaboration to design, purchase and machine materials, secure electronic components, assemble, and commission new two electromagnetic and hadronic calorimeters.  These four detectors, which form the Forward Calorimeter System (FCS), are located close to the RHIC beamline (see Fig. 1) and thus will allow study of the physics of particles created in high-energy collisions of protons or heavy ions that are emitted at far forward angles.  As part of a broader upgrade to the STAR detector, the FCS is joined by two new particle tracking detectors (not part of this award) in the same kinematic region.

STAR is one of the large detector systems operating at RHIC, the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider facility located at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, NY.  Members of the STAR Collaboration – a group of roughly 350 scientists from over 50 universities and institutions – have been collecting and analyzing data at RHIC for over 20 years.  Using collisions of relativistic heavy ions (gold atomic nuclei), RHIC researchers discovered and continue to explore the properties of a new phase of matter, the Quark-Gluon Plasma, or QGP, in which the most basic building blocks of matter, quarks and gluons, are liberated from individual protons and neutrons.  The QGP is believed to have been formed originally as one stage in the early evolution of the universe, existing just a fraction of a second after the Big Bang.  Other members of the STAR Collaboration have focused on learning how these quarks and gluons give rise to the observed properties of the proton by detecting the particles emitted from collisions of high-energy spin-polarized protons.  Surprisingly, most of the proton’s spin – an intrinsic feature of the proton that makes MRI scans possible – is due not to the quarks that make up the proton, but to the short-lived and massless gluons that bind the quarks together.

The new forward detectors at STAR, including the FCS, will enable STAR scientists to explore these exciting discoveries even further, by extending the range over which the collision ‘debris’ can be collected and analyzed.  Data taken with the Forward Upgrade suite of detectors will reveal key details about the state of the gold nuclei just prior to their collisions, which will guide our theoretical understanding of QGP formation.  Studying polarized proton collisions with these detectors will allow us to examine ‘up close’ how the strong nuclear force works, enabling us to map out how the quarks and gluons, and their relative motion, contribute to the proton’s mass and spin.

In addition to the significant scientific output expected from the detectors that were funded through this award, the construction, assembly, testing, and commissioning of the FCS provided an incredibly valuable learning experience for the scores of students, both graduates and undergraduates, who were involved in this work.  Too many of our students in the high-energy community can help take data and lead beautiful physics analyses, yet never participate in a meaningful way in the immense effort required to bring the needed experimental apparatus into existence and make it function correctly.  Though some of the envisioned student help was delayed or otherwise not possible, especially for on-site assembly, due to restrictions imposed for the COVID-19 pandemic, a large number were involved in the initial testing, debugging, and calibration stages, thus grooming a cohort of experts to run and maintain these detectors during RHIC running periods.

Finally, though the FCS was developed in the closing years of the RHIC era, the design and prototyping work funded through this award provided excellent training for professional and technical staff who are now turning their attention to the detectors that will be needed to ensure a successful scientific program at the Electron-Ion Collider, or EIC.  These are complex devices, as suggested by the side view shown in Fig. 2, and they will become more so in the future.  It is fortunate that the calorimetry envisioned for the day-1 detector at the EIC, ePIC, is being developed by many of the same people who performed analogous tasks for the FCS, and what they have learned from the experiences funded through this award will be of great benefit to that project as well.
